## Group Chairman's statement

José Viñals Group Chairman

<!-- image -->

' Leading with our purpose to realise our full potential'

2020 was a year of extraordinary global turbulence, and COVID-19 in particular had a profound impact on all of us. The world is a very different place from this time last year and we all must continue to adjust and adapt. We have very sadly lost colleagues and some of you will have also lost friends and loved ones, so I would like to extend my deepest sympathy to everyone who has suffered during the pandemic.

Throughout this tumultuous period, our 89,000 colleagues around the world - led by our Chief Executive Bill Winters and colleagues in the Management Team - have focused on protecting the interests of shareholders, while ensuring the wellbeing of colleagues, supporting our customers and clients, and showing solidar/i.rightty with our communit/i.rightes. All of this while preserving our operational and financ/i.rightal resil/i.rightence.

They have done this demonstrating exemplary character and with great humanity, something that I have always said is a dist/i.rightnctive characterist/i.rightc of this Group.

Repayment holidays, fee waivers and loan extensions were offered to ind/i.rightvidual and small business customers, and we made $1 bill/i.righton of financ/i.rightng available at cost to those provid/i.rightng crit/i.rightcal goods and services in the fight against the virus. We also established a $50 mill/i.righton Global Charitable Fund to help those affected with/i.rightn our communit/i.rightes. So far, we have donated $28 mill/i.righton across 59 markets, with a comparable sum contributed by colleagues and the Group to support and stimulate economic recovery.

## A resil/i.rightent financ/i.rightal performance, enabling a return to capital distr/i.rightbutions

Bill and Andy Halford, our Chief Financ/i.rightal Officer, will explain in more detail later in this report how our financ/i.rightal performance was impacted in some respects by the effects of the pandemic. But those results also show evidence of great resil/i.rightence - certainly far greater resil/i.rightence than I suspect would have been the case if the pandemic had occurred a few years ago.

Our profit reduced despite lower costs due to a combinat/i.righton of lower interest rates that affected income and higher impa/i.rightrments driven in part by the reserves that we built to absorb possible future credit losses as the pandemic unfolds. But we remained highly liqu/i.rightd and our capital posit/i.righton actually strengthened further, which means that with better vis/i.rightbil/i.rightt y over the near-term economic outlook the Board is recommending the payment of a full-year ordinary div/i.rightdend of $284 mill/i.righton or 9 cents per share.

And with our common equity tier 1 capital ratio above the top end of our 13-14 per cent target range, even after accruing for the recommended ordinary div/i.rightdend, we have decided to complete the share buy-back programme that was suspended in April 2020, meaning we will shortly start purchasing and then cancelling up to $254 mill/i.righton worth of ordinary shares.

The proposed full-year div/i.rightdend and share buy-back programme together is the maximum we are authorised by our regulator to return to shareholders at this stage, being 0.2/uni00A0per cent of our risk-weighted assets as at 31 December 2020.

The Board's posit/i.righton on capital returns remains essentially the same as it was before our regulator requested us to withdraw the recommended 2019 final div/i.rightdend. Having now resumed it, we expect to be able to increase the full-year div/i.rightdend per share over time as we execute our strategy and progress towards a 10 per cent return on tangible equity. To the extent addit/i.rightonal capital generated over that period is not needed to fund further business growth, we will continue to find optimal ways of returning the excess to our owners.

## Governance

I am delighted to welcome Maria Ramos to our Board as an independent non-executive director. She brings considerable experience as a chief executive, sign/i.rightficant understanding of the global financ/i.rightal services industry, an in-depth understanding of the regulatory landscape, as well as experience of operating across many of our markets, especially in the Africa region.

We welcome the appointment of Dr Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala as the new Director-General of the World Trade Organisat/i.righton, as a result of which she will shortly step down from the Board. I would like to thank Dr Ngozi for her valuable contribut/i.rightons to the Group over the last three years.

We recently announced several changes to our Board Committee composit/i.righton, details of which can be found in the Directors' report on page 80. We also recently announced that Robert Zoellick is taking over as chair of our International Advisory Council, a diverse, multid/i.rightscipl/i.rightnary panel of experts whose role is to provide ins/i.rightght on global trends and opportunit/i.rightes that may affect the Group and our clients. Robert served as president of the World Bank from 2007 to 2012, where he led the effort to assist developing economies during the Global Financ/i.rightal Cris/i.rights and held various posts in the US Government over three admin/i.rightstrations.

## What it means to us to be purpose-led

Standard Chartered has a history of being bold and find/i.rightng new opportunit/i.rightes in times of change. For over 160 years we have been pioneers of internat/i.rightonal trade and investment, facil/i.righttating the flow of capital to where it is needed most to drive commerce and prosperity.

And yet, in today's complex, fast-moving and unstable world, it is clear that markets, trade and capital flows are fail/i.rightng to address some of the key socio-economic and environmental challenges of our time. It doesn't need to be this way; we believe commerce and prosperity can be driven without people being left behind, without the planet being negatively impacted, and without creating div/i.rightsions that dim/i.rightnish our sense of community. Never has finance and commerce been more important in fuelling posit/i.rightve change where it matters most - and especially in the world's emerging economic powerhouses.

This is why now, more than ever before, we must lead with our purpose. This is the moment to use our unique capacity to work across boundaries, connecting capital, people, ideas and best practices, both locally and globally. Our convict/i.righton is that we can accelerate our strategy and its wider impact by connecting it to the big issues facing our world. We will take a stand on those issues, reshape our Group where necessary to meet them and grow by playing an active role.

The refreshed strategic prior/i.rightties that Bill describes separately are fully aligned with this object/i.rightve. This is not just about social responsib/i.rightlity. This is fundamentally about doing great business, transforming our franchise and taking our promise of being Here for good to a whole new level. We're determined to unleash a new dynamic in the Group - powered by our purpose. We are build/i.rightng on who we are and what we are good at, and that is why I am confident we can step forward and make a real difference.

## Outlook

So, what does 2021 hold? I hope and expect it will be a better year overall for the world and for us, even if uncertaint/i.rightes continue on several fronts. First, despite the recent posit/i.rightve news on vaccines, we will be coping with the health and economic impact of COVID-19 for some time. Yet I envisage

## Group Chairman's statement continued

that the global economic recovery will strengthen as the year progresses and confidence returns, led by the performance of markets in Asia where we have large and entrenched posit/i.rightons.

Second, geopolit/i.rightcal uncertainty will not disappear under the new US admin/i.rightstration, albeit I expect the US to take a more systematic, predictable and multilateral approach to foreign relations.

Finally, the pace of change required by these new times means things are accelerating faster, not just in the dig/i.righttal space, but also many other parts of the business ecosystem and the world. I expect that this will ultimately result in advances in productiv/i.rightty growth.

There remain plenty of reasons to be confident in this evolving environment. The policy is based on an overrid/i.rightng princ/i.rightple that, to avoid any actual or perceived conflicts of interest, the Group's auditor should only be used when either there is evidence that there is no alternative in terms of quality and there is no conflict with their duties as auditor. ## Movement in gross exposures and credit impa/i.rightrment for loans and advances, debt securit/i.rightes, undrawn commitments and financ/i.rightal guarantees (audited)

The tables overleaf set out the movement in gross exposures and credit impa/i.rightrment by stage in respect of amortised cost loans to banks and customers, undrawn commitments, financ/i.rightal guarantees and debt securit/i.rightes classif/i.righted at amortised cost and FVOCI. ## Methodology

The movement lines with/i.rightn the tables are an aggregation of monthly movements over the year and will therefore reflect the accumulation of multiple trades during the year. The credit impa/i.rightrment charge in the income statement comprises the amounts with/i.rightn the boxes in the table below less recoveries of amounts previously written off. Discount unwind is reported in net interest income and related to stage 3 financ/i.rightal instruments only.

The approach for determin/i.rightng the key line items in the tables is set out below.

- · Transfers - transfers between stages are deemed to occur at the beginn/i.rightng of a month based on prior month closing balances
- · Net remeasurement from stage changes - the remeasurement of credit impa/i.rightrment provis/i.rightons aris/i.rightng from a change in stage is reported with/i.rightn the stage that the assets are transferred to. For example, assets transferred into stage 2 are remeasured from a 12-month to a lifet/i.rightme expected credit loss, with the effect of remeasurement reported in stage 2. For stage 3, this represents the in/i.righttial remeasurement from specif/i.rightc provis/i.rightons recognised on ind/i.rightvidual assets transferred into stage 3 in the year
- · Net changes in exposures - new business written less repayments in the year. With/i.rightn stage 1, new business written will attract up to 12 months of expected credit loss charges. Repayments of non-amortis/i.rightng loans (primar/i.rightly with/i.rightn Corporate & Institut/i.rightonal Banking and Commercial Banking) will have low amounts of expected credit loss provis/i.rightons attributed to them, due to the release of provis/i.rightons over the term to maturity. In stages 2 and 3, the amounts princ/i.rightpally reflect repayments, although stage 2 may include new business written where clients are on non-purely precautionary early alert, are credit grade 12, or when non-investment grade debt securit/i.rightes are acquired.
- · Changes in risk parameters - for stages 1 and 2, this reflects changes in the probabil/i.rightty of default (PD), loss given default (LGD) and exposure at default (EAD) of assets during the year, which includes the impact of releasing provis/i.rightons over the term to maturity. It also includes the effect of changes in forecasts of macroeconomic variables during the year. In stage 3, this line represents addit/i.rightonal specif/i.rightc provis/i.rightons recognised on exposures held with/i.rightn stage 3
- · Interest due but not paid - change in contractual amount of interest due in stage 3 financ/i.rightal instruments but not paid, being the net of accruals, repayments and write-offs, together with the corresponding change in credit impa/i.rightrment

Changes to ECL models, which incorporates changes to model approaches and methodologies, is not reported as a separate line item as it has an impact over a number of lines and stages.

## Movements during the period

Stage 1 gross exposures increased by $31 bill/i.righton to $643 bill/i.righton when compared with 31 December 2019. This was largely due to an increase of $14.7 bill/i.righton in Retail Banking, of which $10 bill/i.righton related to new mortgage lending and $4.7 bill/i.righton to credit cards and personal loans (CCPL) and other unsecured lending. Holdings of debt securit/i.rightes also increased, up by $11 bill/i.righton primar/i.rightly due to sovereign exposures. These increases were partly offset by a reduction in Commercial Banking balances, down $3.4 bill/i.righton, from a number of corporate repayments mainly in the Greater China & North Asia region. ## COVID-19 relief measures

COVID-19 payment-related relief measures are in place across most of our markets, particularly focused on Retail and Business Banking customers. These schemes are generally in/i.righttiated by country regulators and governments. Measures include princ/i.rightpal and/or interest moratoria and term extensions, and are generally available to elig/i.rightble borrowers (those that are current or less than 30 days past due, unless local regulators have specif/i.righted different criter/i.righta). Certain schemes may be restricted to those in industr/i.rightes sign/i.rightficantly impacted by COVID-19, such as aviat/i.righton or consumer services, but are not borrower-specif/i.rightc in nature.

Relief measures are generally mandated or supported by regulators and governments and are available to all elig/i.rightble customers who request it. However, in a number of countries, particularly in ASEAN & South Asia and Africa & Middle East, compulsory (regulatory approved) moratoria reliefs are applied to all elig/i.rightble loans unless a customer has specif/i.rightcally asked to opt out.

In most major Retail Banking markets, the period of relief provided is between 6 and 12 months. In some smaller markets, reliefs are in place for 3 months.

COVID-19 related tenor extensions have also been made available to Corporate & Institut/i.rightonal Banking and Commercial Banking clients, primar/i.rightly for periods between 3 to 9 months, if they are expected to return to normal payments with/i.rightn 12 months.

## Assessment for expected credit losses

COVID-19 payment reliefs that are generally available to a market or industry as a whole and are not borrower-specif/i.rightc in nature have not, on their own, resulted in an automatic change in stage (that is, ind/i.rightvidual customers are not considered to have experienced a sign/i.rightficant increase in credit risk or an improvement in credit risk) nor have they been considered to be forborne.

A customer's stage and past due status reflects their status immed/i.rightately prior to the granting of the relief, with past due amounts assessed based on the new terms as set out in the temporary payment reliefs.

If a customer requires addit/i.rightonal support after the expiry of the in/i.righttial payment relief period, these will be considered at a borrower level, after taking into account their ind/i.rightvidual circumstances. Depending on the type of subsequent support provided, these customers may be classif/i.righted with/i.rightn stage 2 or stage 3.

Where client-level government guarantees are in place, these do not affect staging but are taken into account when determin/i.rightng the level of credit impa/i.rightrment.

## Collateral and other credit enhancements possessed or called upon (audited)

The Group obtains assets by taking possession of collateral or calling upon other credit enhancements (such as guarantees). Repossessed properties are sold in an orderly fashion. Where the proceeds are in excess of the outstanding loan balance the excess is returned to the borrower.

Certain equity securit/i.rightes acquired may be held by the Group for investment purposes and are classif/i.righted as fair value through profit or loss, and the related loan written off. ## Other Credit Risk mit/i.rightgation (audited)

Other forms of Credit Risk mit/i.rightgation are set out below.

## Credit default swaps

The Group has entered into credit default swaps for portfolio management purposes, referencing loan assets with a notional value of $10.5 bill/i.righton (2019: $14.5 bill/i.righton). These credit default swaps are accounted for as financ/i.rightal guarantees as per IFRS 9 as they will only reimburse the holder for an incurred loss on an underlying debt instrument. The Group continues to hold the underlying assets referenced in the credit default swaps and it continues to be exposed to related Credit and Foreign Exchange Risk on these assets.

## Credit linked notes

The Group has issued credit linked notes for portfolio management purposes, referencing loan assets with a notional value of $8.0 bill/i.righton (2019: $4.5 bill/i.righton). The Group continues to hold the underlying assets for which the credit linked notes provide mit/i.rightgation.

## Derivat/i.rightve financ/i.rightal instruments

The Group enters into master netting agreements, which in the event of default result in a single amount owed by or to the counterparty through netting the sum of the posit/i.rightve and negative mark-to-market values of applicable derivat/i.rightve transactions. These are set out in more detail under Derivat/i.rightve financ/i.rightal instruments Credit Risk mit/i.rightgation (page 237).

## Off-balance sheet exposures

For certain types of exposures, such as letters of credit and guarantees, the Group obtains collateral such as cash depending on internal Credit Risk assessments, as well as in the case of letters of credit holding legal title to the underlying assets should a default take place.

## Industry and Retail Products analysis of loans and advances by geographic region

This section provides an analysis of the Group's amortised cost loan portfolio, net of provis/i.rightons, by industry and region.

## Applicat/i.righton of lifet/i.rightme

Expected credit loss is estimated based on the period over which the Group is exposed to Credit Risk. For the major/i.rightty of exposures this equates to the maximum contractual period. For Retail Banking credit cards and Corporate & Institut/i.rightonal Banking overdraft facil/i.rightties however, the Group does not typically enforce the contractual period, which can be as short as one day. As a result, the period over which the Group is exposed to Credit Risk for these instruments reflects their behavioural life, which incorporates expectations of customer behaviour and the extent to which Credit Risk management actions curtail the period of that exposure. The average behavioural life for Retail Banking credit cards is between 3 and 6 years across our footprint markets.

In 2020, the behavioural life for corporate overdraft facil/i.rightties was re-estimated using recent data, and a lifet/i.rightme of 24 months is now being applied (2019: 32 months). The change in approach does not have a material impact on the income statement.

## Key assumptions and judgements in determin/i.rightng expected credit loss

## Incorporation of forward-looking informat/i.righton

The evolving economic environment is a key determinant of the abil/i.rightty of a bank's clients to meet their obligat/i.rightons as they fall due. It is a fundamental princ/i.rightple of IFRS 9 that the provis/i.rightons banks hold against potential future Credit Risk losses should depend not just on the health of the economy today but should also take into account potential changes to the economic environment. For example, if a bank were to antic/i.rightpate a sharp slowdown in the world economy over the coming year, it should hold more provis/i.rightons today to absorb the credit losses likely to occur in the near future.

To capture the effect of changes to the economic environment, the PDs and LGDs used to calculate ECL incorporate forward-looking informat/i.righton in the form of forecasts of the values of economic variables and asset prices that are likely to have an effect on the repayment abil/i.rightty of the Group's clients.

The 'Base Forecast' of the economic variables and asset prices is based on management's view on the five-year outlook, supported by project/i.rightons from the Group's in-house research team and outputs from a third-party model that project specif/i.rightc economic variables and asset prices. The research team takes consensus views into considerat/i.righton and senior management review project/i.rightons for some core country variables against consensus when forming their view of the outlook. For the period beyond five years, management util/i.rightses the in-house research view and third-party model outputs, which allow for a reversion to long-term growth rates or norms. All project/i.rightons are updated on a quarterly basis.

## Forecast of key macroeconomic variables underlying the expected credit loss calculation and the impact on non-linear/i.rightty

The Base Forecast - management's view of the most likely outcome - is that the prospects for a path out of the COVID-19 cris/i.rights have improved with progress on vaccines and virus treatments. Early into the new year, this has raised confidence over the economic outlook and is expected to support the recovery of economic activ/i.rightty over the next two years. Global GDP is expected to grow by around 5 per cent in 2021, well above the average of 3.7 per cent for the ten years between 2010 to 2019. However, this follows a contraction of almost 4 per cent in 2020, the worst performance since the Great Depression of 1929-31.

Key to the outlook is the assumption that vaccines will be rolled out early in 2021 in major markets, and reach the major/i.rightty of the population by the third quarter of the year. In addit/i.righton, renewed virus outbreaks in many countries are expected to be contained. The global economic recovery will strengthen in the second half of 2021 as investment picks up around the world.

With the global recovery under way, many countries are expected to be close to their forward-looking long-term or future potential - growth levels by the end of the next two years. However, the outlook remains highly uncertain. A faster distr/i.rightbution of vaccines will likely support stronger growth, while delays and disrupt/i.rightons will hold it back. The current (and any future) resurgence of the virus in many countries could also force governments to tighten restrict/i.rightons on economic activ/i.rightty for longer than antic/i.rightpated.

While the quarterly base forecasts inform the Group's strategic plan, one key requirement of IFRS 9 is that the assessment of provis/i.rightons should consider multiple future economic environments. For example, the global economy may grow more quickly or more slowly than the Base Forecast, and these variat/i.rightons would have different impl/i.rightcations for the provis/i.rightons that the Group should hold today. As the negative impact of an economic downturn on credit losses tends to be greater than the posit/i.rightve impact of an economic upturn, if the Group sets provis/i.rightons only on the ECL under the Base Forecast it might mainta/i.rightn a level of provis/i.rightons that does not appropriately capture the range of potential outcomes. To address this property of skewness (or non-linear/i.rightty), IFRS 9 requires reported ECL to be a probabil/i.rightty-weighted ECL calculated over a range of possible outcomes.

To assess the range of possible outcomes, the Group simulates a set of 50 scenarios around the Base Forecast, calculates the ECL under each of them and assigns an equal weight of 2 per cent to each scenario outcome. These scenarios are generated by a Monte Carlo simulat/i.righton, which addresses the challenges of crafting many realist/i.rightc alternative scenarios in the many countries in which the Group operates by means of a model, which produces these alternative scenarios while consider/i.rightng the degree of histor/i.rightcal uncertainty (or volatil/i.rightty) observed over 1Q'90 to 3Q'20 around economic outcomes and how these outcomes have tended to move in relation to one another (or correlation). This naturally means that each of the 50 scenarios do not have a specif/i.rightc narrative, although collectively they explore a range of hypothetical alternative outcomes for the global economy, includ/i.rightng scenarios that turn out better than expected and scenarios that amplify antic/i.rightpated stresses.

## Sign/i.rightficant increase in credit risk (SICR) Quantitat/i.rightve criter/i.righta

SICR is assessed by comparing the risk of default at the reporting date to the risk of default at orig/i.rightnation. Whether a change in the risk of default is sign/i.rightficant or not is assessed using quantitat/i.rightve and qualitat/i.rightve criter/i.righta. These quantitat/i.rightve sign/i.rightficant deteriorat/i.righton thresholds have been separately defined for each business and where meaningful are consistently applied across business lines.

Assets are considered to have experienced SICR if they have breached both relative and absolute thresholds for the change in the average annualised lifet/i.rightme probabil/i.rightty of default over the residual term of the exposure.

The absolute measure of increase in credit risk is used to capture instances where the PDs on exposures are relatively low at in/i.righttial recognit/i.righton as these may increase by several multiples without representing a sign/i.rightficant increase in credit risk. Where PDs are relatively high at in/i.righttial recognit/i.righton, a relative measure is more appropriate in assessing whether there is a sign/i.rightficant increase in credit risk, as the PDs increase more quickly.

The SICR thresholds have been calibrated based on the following princ/i.rightples:

- · Stabil/i.rightty - The thresholds are set to achieve a stable stage 2 population at a portfolio level, trying to min/i.rightmise the number of accounts moving back and forth between stage 1 and stage 2 in a short period of time
- · Accuracy - The thresholds are set such that there is a materially higher propensity for stage 2 exposures to eventually default than is the case for stage 1 exposures
- · Dependency from backstops - The thresholds are stringent enough such that a high proportion of accounts transfer to stage 2 due to movements in forward-looking PD rather than relying on backward-looking backstops such as arrears
- · Relationsh/i.rightp with business and product risk profiles The thresholds reflect the relative risk differences between different products, and are aligned to business processes

For Corporate & Institut/i.rightonal Banking and Commercial Banking clients, the relative threshold is a 100 per cent increase in PD and the absolute change in PD is between 50 and 100 bps.

For Retail Banking clients, the relative threshold is a 100 per cent increase in PD and the absolute change in PD is between 100 and 350 bps depending on the product. Certain countries have a higher absolute threshold reflecting the lower default rate with/i.rightn their personal loan portfolios compared with the Group's other personal loan portfolios.

Private Banking clients are assessed qualitat/i.rightvely, based on a delinquency measure relating to collateral top-ups or sell-downs.

Debt securit/i.rightes orig/i.rightnated before 1 January 2018, with an internal credit rating mapped to an investment grade equivalent, are allocated to stage 1 and all other debt securit/i.rightes to stage 2. Debt securit/i.rightes orig/i.rightnated after 1 January 2018 apply the same approach and thresholds as for Corporate & Institut/i.rightonal Banking and Commercial Banking clients.

## Derivat/i.rightve financ/i.rightal instruments Credit Risk mit/i.rightgation

The Group enters into master netting agreements, which in the event of default result in a single amount owed by or to the counterparty through netting the sum of the posit/i.rightve and negative mark-to-market values of applicable derivat/i.rightve transactions. ## Stressed coverage

The Group intends to mainta/i.rightn a prudent and sustainable funding and liqu/i.rightdity posit/i.righton, in all countries and currencies, such that it can withstand a severe but plausible liqu/i.rightdity stress.

Our approach to managing liqu/i.rightdity and funding is reflected in the following Board-level Risk Appetite Statement:

'The Group should hold an adequate buffer of high-quality liqu/i.rightd assets to survive extreme but plausible liqu/i.rightdity stress scenarios for at least 60 days without recourse to extraordinary central bank support.'

The Group's internal liqu/i.rightdity stress testing framework covers the following stress scenarios:

- · Standard Chartered-specif/i.rightc - This scenario captures the liqu/i.rightdity impact from an id/i.rightosyncratic event affecting Standard Chartered only i.e. the rest of the market is assumed to operate normally.
- · Market wide - This scenario captures the liqu/i.rightdity impact from a market-wide cris/i.rights affecting all partic/i.rightpants in a country, region or globally.
- · Combined - This scenario assumes both Standard Chartered-specif/i.rightc and Market-wide events affecting the Group simultaneously and hence is the most severe scenario.

All scenarios include, but are not lim/i.rightted to, modelled outflows for retail and wholesale funding, Off-Balance Sheet Funding Risk, Cross Currency Funding Risk, Intraday Risk, Franchise Risk and risks associated with a deteriorat/i.righton of a firm's credit rating.

Stress testing results show that a posit/i.rightve surplus was mainta/i.rightned under all scenarios at 31 December 2020, i.e. respective countries are able to survive for a period of time as defined under each scenario. The combined scenario at 31 December 2020 showed the Group mainta/i.rightned liqu/i.rightdity resources to survive greater than 60 days, as per our Board Risk Appetite. ## Advances-to-deposits ratio

This is defined as the ratio of total loans and advances to customers relative to total customer accounts. An advancesto-deposits ratio of below 100 per cent demonstrates that customer deposits exceed customer loans as a result of the emphasis placed on generating a high level of funding from customers.

## Net stable funding ratio (NSFR)

On 23 November 2016, the European Commiss/i.righton, as part of a package of risk-reducing measures, proposed a regulatory requirement for stable funding (net stable funding ratio (NSFR)) at European Union level. The proposal aims to implement the European Banking Authority's interpretat/i.righton of the Basel standard on NSFR (BCBS295). The NSFR is due to become a regulatory requirement in January 2022 with a min/i.rightmum of 100 per cent. Pending implementat/i.righton of the final rules, the Group continues to monitor NSFR in line with the BCBS' final recommendation (BCBS295).

The NSFR is a balance sheet metric which requires inst/i.righttutions to mainta/i.rightn a stable funding profile in relation to the characterist/i.rightcs of their assets and off-balance sheet activ/i.rightties over a one-year horizon. It is the ratio between the amount of available stable funding (ASF) and the amount of required

stable funding (RSF). ASF factors are applied to balance sheet liab/i.rightlit/i.rightes and capital, based on their perceived stabil/i.rightty and the amount of stable funding they provide. Likew/i.rightse, RSF factors are applied to assets and off-balance sheet exposures according to the amount of stable funding they require. At the last reporting date, the Group NSFR remained above 100 per cent.

## Accounting policy

Interest income for financ/i.rightal assets held at either fair value through other comprehensive income or amortised cost, and interest expense on all financ/i.rightal liab/i.rightlit/i.rightes held at amortised cost is recognised in profit or loss using the effective interest method.

The effective interest method is a method of calculating the amortised cost of a financ/i.rightal asset or a financ/i.rightal liab/i.rightlity and of allocating the interest income or interest expense over the relevant period. The effective interest rate is the rate that discounts estimated future cash payments or receipts through the expected life of the financ/i.rightal instrument or, when appropriate, a shorter period, to the net carrying amount of the financ/i.rightal asset or financ/i.rightal liab/i.rightlity. When calculating the effective interest rate, the Group estimates cash flows consider/i.rightng all contractual terms of the financ/i.rightal instrument (for example, prepayment options) but does not consider future credit losses. The calculation includes all fees paid or received between parties to the contract that are an integral part of the effective interest rate, transaction costs and all other premiums or discounts. Where the estimates of cash flows have been revised, the carrying amount of the financ/i.rightal asset or liab/i.rightlity is adjusted to reflect the actual and revised cash flows, discounted at the instrument's orig/i.rightnal effective interest rate. The adjustment is recognised as interest income or expense in the period in which the revis/i.righton is made.

Interest income for financ/i.rightal assets that are either held at fair value through other comprehensive income or amortised cost that have become credit-impa/i.rightred subsequent to in/i.righttial recognit/i.righton (stage 3) and have had amounts written off, is recognised using the credit-adjusted effective interest rate. This rate is calculated in the same manner as the effective interest rate except that expected credit losses are included in the expected cash flows. Interest income is therefore recognised on the amortised cost of the financ/i.rightal asset includ/i.rightng expected credit losses. Should the Credit Risk on a stage 3 financ/i.rightal asset improve such that the financ/i.rightal asset is no longer considered credit-impa/i.rightred, interest income recognit/i.righton reverts to a computation based on the rehabil/i.righttated gross carrying value of the financ/i.rightal asset.

The Group applies the following practical expedients:

- · Promised considerat/i.righton is not adjusted for the effects of a sign/i.rightficant financ/i.rightng component as the period between the Group provid/i.rightng a service and the customer paying for it is expected to be less than one year
- · Incremental costs of obtain/i.rightng a fee-earning contract are recognised upfront in 'Fees and commiss/i.righton expense' rather than amortised, if the expected term of the contract is less than one year

The determinat/i.righton of the services performed for the customer, the transaction price, and when the services are completed depends on the nature of the product with the customer. The main considerat/i.rightons on income recognit/i.righton by product are as follows:

## Transaction Banking

The Group recognises fee income associated with transactional trade and cash management at the point in time the service is provided. The Group recognises income associated with trade contingent risk exposures (such as letters of credit and guarantees) over the period in which the service is provided.

Payment of fees is usually received at the same time the service is provided. In some cases, letters of credit and guarantees issued by the Group have annual upfront premiums, which are amortised on a straight-line basis to fee income over the year.

## Financ/i.rightal Markets and Corporate Finance

The Group recognises fee income at the point in time the service is provided. ## Accounting policy

The Group classif/i.rightes its financ/i.rightal assets into the following measurement categories: amortised cost; fair value through other comprehensive income (FVOCI); and fair value through profit or loss. Financ/i.rightal liab/i.rightlit/i.rightes are classif/i.righted as either amortised cost, or held at fair value through profit or loss. ## Financ/i.rightal assets held at amortised cost and fair value through other comprehensive income

Princ/i.rightpal is the fair value of the financ/i.rightal asset at in/i.righttial recognit/i.righton but this may change over the life of the instrument as amounts are repaid. - · Credit valuation adjustment (CVA): The Group accounts for CVA against the fair value of derivat/i.rightve products. ## Level 3 Summary and sign/i.rightficant unobservable inputs continued

The following section describes the sign/i.rightficant unobservable inputs ident/i.rightfied in the valuation technique table:

- · Comparable price/yield is a valuation methodology in which the price of a comparable instrument is used to estimate the fair value where there are no direct observable prices. Yield is the interest rate that is used to discount the future cash flows in a discounted cash flow model. Valuation using comparable instruments can be done by calculating an impl/i.righted yield (or spread over a liqu/i.rightd benchmark) from the price of a comparable instrument, then adjust/i.rightng that yield (or spread) to derive a value for the instrument. The adjustment should account for relevant differences in the financ/i.rightal instruments such as maturity and/or credit quality. Alternatively, a price-to-price basis can be assumed between the comparable instrument and the instrument being valued in order to establish the value of the instrument (for example, deriv/i.rightng a fair value for a jun/i.rightor unsecured bond from the price of a senior secured bond). An increase in price, in isolat/i.righton, would result in a favourable movement in the fair value of the asset. An increase in yield, in isolat/i.righton, would result in an unfavourable movement in the fair value of the asset
- · Correlation is the measure of how movement in one variable influences the movement in another variable. An equity correlation is the correlation between two equity instruments while an interest rate correlation refers to the correlation between two swap rates
- · Credit spread represents the addit/i.rightonal yield that a market partic/i.rightpant would demand for taking exposure to the Credit Risk of an instrument
- · Discount rate refers to the rate of return used to convert expected cash flows into present value
- · Equity-FX correlation is the correlation between equity instrument and foreign exchange instrument
- · EV/EBITDA ratio multiples is the ratio of Enterprise Value (EV) to Earnings Before Interest, Taxes, Depreciat/i.righton and Amortisat/i.righton (EBITDA). EV is the aggregate market capital/i.rightsation and debt minus the cash and cash equivalents. An increase in EV/EBITDA multiples in isolat/i.righton, will result in a favourable movement in the fair value of the unlisted firm
- · Foreign exchange curves is the term structure for forward rates and swap rates between currency pairs over a specif/i.righted period
- · Interest rate curves is the term structure of interest rates and measure of future interest rates at a particular point in time
- · Liqu/i.rightdity discounts in the valuation of unlisted investments primar/i.rightly applied to the valuation of unlisted firms' investments to reflect the fact that these stocks are not actively traded. An increase in liqu/i.rightdity discount will result in unfavourable movement in the fair value of the unlisted firm
- · Price-Earnings (P/E) multiples is the ratio of the Market Capital/i.rightsation to the net income after tax. The multiples are determined from multiples of listed comparables, which are observable. An increase in P/E multiple will result in a favourable movement in the fair value of the unlisted firm
- · Price-Book (P/B) multiple is the ratio of the market value of equity to the book value of equity. An increase in P/B multiple will result in a favourable movement in the fair value of the unlisted firm
- · Price-Sales (P/S) multiple is the ratio of the market value of equity to sales. An increase in P/S multiple will result in a favourable movement in the fair value of the unlisted firm
- · Recovery rates are the expectation of the rate of return resulting from the liqu/i.rightdation of a particular loan. As the probabil/i.rightty of default increases for a given instrument, the valuation of that instrument will increas/i.rightngly reflect its expected recovery level assuming default. An increase in the recovery rate, in isolat/i.righton, would result in a favourable movement in the fair value of the loan
- · Volatil/i.rightty represents an estimate of how much a particular instrument, parameter or index will change in value over time. Generally, the higher the volatil/i.rightty, the more expensive the option will be

## 14. Derivat/i.rightve financ/i.rightal instruments

## Accounting policy

Derivat/i.rightves are financ/i.rightal instruments that derive their value in response to changes in interest rates, financ/i.rightal instrument prices, commodity prices, foreign exchange rates, credit risk and ind/i.rightces. Derivat/i.rightves are categorised as trading unless they are designated as hedging instruments.

Derivat/i.rightves are in/i.righttially recognised and subsequently measured at fair value, with revaluation gains recognised in profit or loss (except where cash flow or net investment hedging has been achieved, in which case the effective portion of changes in fair value is recognised with/i.rightn other comprehensive income).

Fair values may be obtained from quoted market prices in active markets, recent market transactions, and valuation techniques, includ/i.rightng discounted cash flow models and option pric/i.rightng models, as appropriate. Where the in/i.righttially recognised fair value of a derivat/i.rightve contract is based on a valuation model that uses inputs which are not observable in the market, it follows the same in/i.righttial recognit/i.righton accounting policy as for other financ/i.rightal assets and liab/i.rightlit/i.rightes. All derivat/i.rightves are carried as assets when fair value is posit/i.rightve and as liab/i.rightlit/i.rightes when fair value is negative.

## Hedge accounting

Under certain condit/i.rightons, the Group may designate a recognised asset or liab/i.rightlity, a firm commitment, highly probable forecast transaction or net investment of a foreign operation into a formal hedge accounting relationsh/i.rightp with a derivat/i.rightve that has been entered to manage interest rate and/or foreign exchange risks present in the hedged item. The Group continues to apply the 'Phase 1' hedge accounting requirements of IAS 39 Financ/i.rightal Instruments: Recognit/i.righton and Measurement and has early adopted the 'Phase 2' amendments to IFRS in respect of interest rate benchmark reform. There are three categories of hedge relationsh/i.rightps:

- · Fair value hedge: to manage the fair value of interest rate and/or foreign currency risks of recognised assets or liab/i.rightlit/i.rightes or firm commitments
- · Cash flow hedge: to manage interest rate or foreign exchange risk of highly probable future cash flows attributable to a recognised asset or liab/i.rightlity, or a forecasted transaction
- · Net investment hedge: to manage the structural foreign exchange risk of an investment in a foreign operation

The Group formally documents at the incept/i.righton of the transaction the relationsh/i.rightp between hedging instruments and hedged items, as well as its risk management object/i.rightve and strategy for undertaking hedge transactions. This is described in more detail in the categories of hedges below.

The Group assesses, both at hedge incept/i.righton and on a quarterly basis, whether the derivat/i.rightves designated in hedge relationsh/i.rightps are highly effective in offsetting changes in fair values or cash flows of hedged items. Hedges are considered to be highly effective if all the following criter/i.righta are met:

- · At incept/i.righton of the hedge and throughout its life, the hedge is prospectively expected to be highly effective in achiev/i.rightng offsetting changes in fair value or cash flows attributable to the hedged risk
- · Actual results of the hedge are with/i.rightn a range of 80-125%. This is tested using regression analysis
- · The regression co-effic/i.rightent (R squared), which measures the correlation between the variables in the regression, is at least 80%
- · In the case of the hedge of a forecast transaction, the transaction must have a high probabil/i.rightty of occurring and must present an exposure to variat/i.rightons in cash flows that are expected to affect reported profit or loss. The Group assumes that any interest rate benchmarks on which hedged item cash flows are based are not altered by IBOR reform

The Group discont/i.rightnues hedge accounting in any of the following circumstances:

- · The hedging instrument is not, or has ceased to be, highly effective as a hedge
- · The hedging instrument has expired, is sold, terminated or exercised
- · The hedged item matures, is sold or repaid
- · The forecast transaction is no longer deemed highly probable
- · The Group elects to discont/i.rightnue hedge accounting voluntarily

For interest rate benchmarks deemed in scope of IBOR reform, if the actual result of a hedge is outside the 80-125% range, but the hedge passes the prospective assessment, then the Group will not de-designate the hedge relationsh/i.rightp.

Under the Phase 2 Interest Rate Benchmark Reform amendments to IFRS 9 and IAS 39, the Group may change hedge designat/i.rightons and corresponding documentation without the hedge being discont/i.rightnued where there is a change in interest rate benchmark of the hedged item, hedging instrument or designated hedged risk. Permitted changes include the right to:

- · Redefine the descript/i.righton of the hedged item and/or hedging instrument
- · Redefine the hedged risk to reference an alternative risk-free rate
- · Change the method for assessing hedge effectiveness due to modif/i.rightcations required by IBOR reform

A hedge designat/i.righton may be modif/i.righted more than once, each time a relationsh/i.rightp is affected as a direct result of IBOR reform.

## Fair value hedge

Changes in the fair value of derivat/i.rightves that are designated and qualify as fair value hedging instruments are recorded in net trading income, together with any changes in the fair value of the hedged asset or liab/i.rightlity that are attributable to the hedged risk. For financ/i.rightal assets classif/i.righted as fair value through other comprehensive income, the hedge accounting adjustment attributable to the hedged risk is included in net trading income to match the hedging derivat/i.rightve.

The effective portion of changes in the fair value of derivat/i.rightves that are designated and qualify as cash flow hedging instruments are in/i.righttially recognised in other comprehensive income, accumulating in the cash flow hedge reserve with/i.rightn equity. ## Fair value hedges

The Group issues various long-term fixed rate debt issuances that are measured at amortised cost, includ/i.rightng some denominated in foreign currency, such as unsecured senior and subordinated debt (see Notes 22 and 27). The Group also holds various fixed rate debt securit/i.rightes such as government and corporate bonds, includ/i.rightng some denominated in foreign currency (see Note 13). These assets and liab/i.rightlit/i.rightes held are exposed to changes in fair value due to movements in market interest and foreign currency rates.

The Group uses interest rate swaps to exchange fixed rates for floating rates on funding to match floating rates received on assets, or exchange fixed rates on assets to match floating rates paid on funding. The Group further uses cross currency swaps to match the currency of the issued debt or held asset with that of the entity's functional currency.

Hedge ineffect/i.rightveness from fair value hedges is driven by cross currency basis risk. The amortisat/i.righton of fair value hedge adjustments for hedged items no longer designated is recognised in net trading income. ## Cash flow hedges

The Group has exposure to market movements in future interest cash flows on portfolios of customer accounts, debt securit/i.rightes and loans and advances to customers. The amounts and tim/i.rightng of future cash flows, representing both princ/i.rightpal and interest flows, are projected on the basis of contractual terms and other relevant factors, includ/i.rightng estimates of prepayments and defaults.

The hedging strategy of the Group involves using interest rate swaps to manage the variab/i.rightlity in future cash flows on assets and liab/i.rightlit/i.rightes that have floating rates of interest by exchanging the floating rates for fixed rates. It also uses foreign exchange contracts and currency swaps to manage the variab/i.rightlity in future exchange rates on its assets and liab/i.rightlit/i.rightes and costs in foreign currencies. This is done on both a micro basis whereby a single interest rate or cross currency swap is designated in a separate relationsh/i.rightp with a single hedged item (such as a floating rate loan to a customer), and on a portfolio basis whereby each hedging instrument is designated against a group of hedged items that share the same risk (such as a group of customer accounts).

The hedged risk is determined as the variab/i.rightlity of future cash flows aris/i.rightng from changes in the designated benchmark interest rate, e.g. one-month or three-month LIBOR.

The Group uses foreign exchange forwards to manage the effect of exchange rates on its net investments in foreign subsid/i.rightaries.

## Interest rate benchmark reform

The Group applies the Phase 1 'Interest Rate Benchmark Reform Amendments to IFRS 9, IAS 39 and IFRS 7' which allow the Group to assume that the interest rate benchmark on which cash flows for the hedged item and/or hedging instrument are based is are altered as a result of IBOR reform for the following activ/i.rightties:

- · Prospective hedge assessment
- · Determin/i.rightng whether a cash flow or forecast transaction for a cash flow hedge is highly probable. However, the Group otherwise assesses whether the cash flows are considered highly probable
- · Determin/i.rightng when cumulative balances in the cash flow hedge reserve from de-designated hedges should be recycled to the income statement

The Group will not de-designate a hedge relationsh/i.rightp of a benchmark in scope of IBOR reform if the retrospective hedge result is outside the required 80-125% range but, the hedge passes the prospective assessment. Any hedge ineffect/i.rightveness continues to be recorded in net trading income.

For hedges of non-contractually specif/i.righted benchmark portions of an interest rate (such as fair value hedges of interest rate risk on fixed rate debt instruments) the Group only assesses whether the designated benchmark is separately ident/i.rightfiable at hedge incept/i.righton. The choice of designated benchmark is not revis/i.rightted for exist/i.rightng hedge relationsh/i.rightps.

In applying these amendments, the Group has made the following key assumptions for the period end, to be reviewed on an ongoing basis:

- · The interest rate benchmarks applicable to the Group that are in scope of the IFRS amendments are all LIBORs, EONIA, Singapore Swap Offer Rate (SGD SOR) and Thai Baht Interest Rate Fix/i.rightng (THB FIX)
- · EURIBOR is not in scope of the IFRS amendments because its revised methodology incorporates market transaction data, hence the benchmark is expected to continue to exist in future reporting periods
- · The Group believes it is too early to reliably estimate when interest rate benchmark uncertainty will be resolved for all benchmarks assumed to be in scope of the amendments. It therefore assumes that the uncertainty aris/i.rightng from interest rate benchmark reform will be present until 31 December 2021, at which time the amendments to IFRS no longer apply

The Group has established an IBOR Transit/i.righton Programme that is overseen by the Group's Chief Operating Officer, and updates a number of committees includ/i.rightng the Board Risk Committee and Group Risk Committee regularly updated. The programme comprises a series of business and function workstreams, with oversight and coordinat/i.righton of the specif/i.rightc areas and risks provided by a central project team. The key object/i.rightves of these workstreams include ident/i.rightfying all contracts in scope of benchmark reform, upgrading internal systems to support business in the alternative RFR product suite, ident/i.rightfying and communicat/i.rightng to customers with whom repric/i.rightng and/or re-papering IBOR-referenced contracts is required and executing the necessary change in contracts. Workstreams actively partic/i.rightpate in industry-wide working groups to ensure they are kept informed of the latest developments and are consistent with the approaches of other market partic/i.rightpants.

## 16. Reverse repurchase and repurchase agreements includ/i.rightng other sim/i.rightlar lending and borrowing

## Accounting policy

The Group purchases securit/i.rightes (a reverse repurchase agreement - 'reverse repo') typically with financ/i.rightal inst/i.righttutions subject to a commitment to resell or return the securit/i.rightes at a predetermined price. These securit/i.rightes are not included in the balance sheet as the Group does not acquire the risks and rewards of ownership, however they are recorded off-balance sheet as collateral received. Considerat/i.righton paid (or cash collateral provided) is accounted for as a loan asset at amortised cost, unless it is managed on a fair value basis or designated at fair value through profit or loss. In the major/i.rightty of cases through the contractual terms of a reverse repo arrangement, the Group as the transferee of the security collateral has the right to sell or repledge the asset concerned.

The Group also sells securit/i.rightes (a repurchase agreement - 'repo') subject to a commitment to repurchase or redeem the securit/i.rightes at a predetermined price. The securit/i.rightes are retained on the balance sheet as the Group retains substantially all the risks and rewards of ownership and these securit/i.rightes are disclosed as pledged collateral. Considerat/i.righton received (or cash collateral received) is accounted for as a financ/i.rightal liab/i.rightlity at amortised cost, unless it is either mandatorily classif/i.righted as fair value through profit or loss or irrevocably designated at fair value through profit or loss at in/i.righttial recognit/i.righton.

Financ/i.rightal assets are pledged as collateral as part of sales and repurchases, securit/i.rightes borrowing and securit/i.rightsation transactions under terms that are usual and customary for such activ/i.rightties. The Group is obliged to return equivalent securit/i.rightes.

Repo and reverse repo transactions typically entitle the Group and its counterparties to have recourse to assets sim/i.rightlar to those provided as collateral in the event of a default. Securit/i.rightes sold subject to repos, either by way of a Global Master Repurchase Agreement (GMRA), or through a securit/i.rightes sale and Total Return Swap (TRS) continue to be recognised on the balance sheet as the Group retains substantially the associated risks and rewards of the securit/i.rightes (the TRS is not recognised). The counterparty liab/i.rightlity is included in deposits by banks or customer accounts, as appropriate. Assets sold under repurchase agreements are considered encumbered as the Group cannot pledge these to obtain funding.

## Accounting policy

## Goodwill

Goodwill represents the excess of the cost of an acquis/i.righttion over the fair value of the Group's share of the ident/i.rightfiable net assets and contingent liab/i.rightlit/i.rightes of the acquired subsid/i.rightary, associate or jo/i.rightnt venture at the date of acquis/i.righttion. Goodwill on acquis/i.righttions of subsid/i.rightaries is included in intang/i.rightble assets. Goodwill on acquis/i.righttions of associates is included in Investments in associates. Goodwill included in Intangible assets is assessed at each balance sheet date for impa/i.rightrment and carried at cost less any accumulated impa/i.rightrment losses. Goodwill is allocated to CGUs for the purpose of impa/i.rightrment testing. CGUs represent the lowest level with/i.rightn the Group which generate separate cash inflows and at which the goodwill is monitored for internal management purposes. These are equal to or smaller than the Group's reportable segments (as set out in Note 2) as the Group views its reportable segments on a global basis. The major CGUs to which goodwill has been allocated are set out in the CGU table (page 368).

## Sign/i.rightficant accounting estimates and judgements

Estimates include forecasts used for determin/i.rightng cash flows for CGUs, the appropriate long term growth rates to use and discount rates which factor in country risk-free rates and applicable risk premiums. The estimat/i.righton of future cash flows and the level to which they are discounted is inherently uncertain and requires sign/i.rightficant judgement and is subject to potential change over time.

## Acquired intang/i.rightbles

At the date of acquis/i.righttion of a subsid/i.rightary or associate, intang/i.rightble assets which are deemed separable and that arise from contractual or other legal rights are capital/i.rightsed and included with/i.rightn the net ident/i.rightfiable assets acquired. The Group assesses whether a contract is a lease in scope of this policy by determin/i.rightng whether the contract gives it the right to use a specif/i.righted underlying physical asset for a lease term greater than 12 months, unless the underlying asset is of low value.

## Accounting policy

The Group operates pension and other post-retirement benefit plans around the world, which can be categorised into defined contribut/i.righton plans and defined benefit plans. For defined contribut/i.righton plans, the Group pays contribut/i.rightons to publicly or privately admin/i.rightstered pension plans on a statutory or contractual basis, and such amounts are charged to operating expenses. The Group has no further payment obligat/i.rightons once the contribut/i.rightons have been paid.

For funded defined benefit plans, the liab/i.rightlity recognised in the balance sheet is the present value of the defined benefit obligat/i.righton at the balance sheet date less the fair value of plan assets. For unfunded defined benefit plans the liab/i.rightlity recognised at the balance sheet date is the present value of the defined benefit obligat/i.righton.

The defined benefit obligat/i.righton is calculated annually by independent actuaries using the projected unit method.

Actuarial gains and losses that arise are recognised in shareholders' equity and presented in the statement of other comprehensive income in the period they arise. The Group determines the net interest expense on the net defined benefit liab/i.rightlity for the year by applying the discount rate used to measure the defined benefit obligat/i.righton at the beginn/i.rightng of the annual period to the net defined benefit liab/i.rightlity, taking into account any changes in the net defined benefit liab/i.rightlity during the year as a result of contribut/i.rightons and benefit payments. Net interest expense, the cost of the accrual of new benefits, benefit enhancements (or reductions) and admin/i.rightstration expenses met directly from plan assets are recognised in the income statement in the period in which they were incurred.

## Sign/i.rightficant accounting estimates and judgements

There are many factors that affect the measurement of the retirement benefit obligat/i.rightons. This measurement requires the use of estimates, such as discount rates, inflat/i.righton, pension increases, salary increases, and life expectancies which are inherently uncertain. Discount rates are determined by reference to market yields at the end of the reporting period on high-quality corporate bonds (or, in countries where there is no deep market in such bonds, government bonds) of a currency and term consistent with the currency and term of the post-employment benefit obligat/i.rightons. This is the approach adopted across our geographies. Where there are inflat/i.righton-linked bonds available (e.g. United Kingdom and the eurozone), the Group derives inflat/i.righton based on the market on those bonds, with the market yield adjusted in respect of the United Kingdom to take account of the fact that liab/i.rightlit/i.rightes are linked to Consumer Price Index inflat/i.righton, whereas the reference bonds are linked to Retail Price Index inflat/i.righton. Where no inflat/i.righton-linked bonds exist, we determine inflat/i.righton assumptions based on a combinat/i.righton of long-term forecasts and short-term inflat/i.righton data. Salary growth assumptions reflect the Group's long-term expectations, taking into account future business plans and macroeconomic data (primar/i.rightly expected future long-term inflat/i.righton). ## Accounting policy

The Group operates equity-settled and cash-settled share-based compensation plans. The fair value of the employee services (measured by the fair value of the awards granted) received in exchange for the grant of the shares and awards is recognised as an expense. For deferred share awards granted as part of an annual performance award, the expense is recognised over the period from the start of the performance period to the vesting date. For example, the expense for three-year awards granted in 2021 in respect of 2020 performance, which vest in 2022-24, is recognised as an expense over the period from 1 January 2020 to the vesting dates in 2022-24. For all other awards, the expense is recognised over the period from the date of grant to the vesting date.

For equity-settled awards, the total amount to be expensed over the vesting period is determined by reference to the fair value of the shares and awards at the date of grant, which excludes the impact of any non-market vesting condit/i.rightons (for example, profitab/i.rightlity and growth targets). The fair value of equity instruments granted is based on market prices, if available, at the date of grant. In the absence of market prices, the fair value of the instruments is estimated using an appropriate valuation technique, such as a binom/i.rightal option pric/i.rightng model. Non-market vesting condit/i.rightons are included in assumptions for the number of shares and awards that are expected to vest.

At each balance sheet date, the Group revises its estimates of the number of shares and awards that are expected to vest. It recognises the impact of the revis/i.righton of orig/i.rightnal estimates, if any, in the income statement and a corresponding adjustment to equity over the remain/i.rightng vesting period. Forfeitures prior to vesting attributable to factors other than the failure to satisfy service condit/i.rightons and non-market vesting condit/i.rightons are treated as a cancellation and the remain/i.rightng unamortised charge is debited to the income statement at the time of cancellation. The proceeds received net of any directly attributable transaction costs are credited to share capital (nominal value) and share premium when awards in the form of options are exercised.

Cash-settled awards are revalued at each balance sheet date and a liab/i.rightlity recognised on the balance sheet for all unpaid amounts, with any changes in fair value charged or credited to staff costs in the income statement until the awards are exercised. Where forfeitures occur prior to vesting that are attributable to factors other than a failure to satisfy service condit/i.rightons or market-based performance condit/i.rightons, the cumulative charge incurred up to the date of forfeiture is credited to the income statement. Any revaluation related to cash-settled awards is recorded as an amount due from subsid/i.rightary undertakings.

## Accounting policy

## Subsid/i.rightaries

Subsid/i.rightaries are all entit/i.rightes, includ/i.rightng structured entit/i.rightes, which the Group controls. The Group controls an entity when it is exposed to, and has rights to, variable returns from its involvement with the entity and has the abil/i.rightty to affect those returns through its power over the investee. The assessment of power is based on the Group's practical abil/i.rightty to direct the relevant activ/i.rightties of the entity unilaterally for the Group's own benefit and is subject to reassessment if and when one or more of the elements of control change. Subsid/i.rightaries are fully consolidated from the date on which the Group effectively obtains control. They are deconsolidated from the date that control ceases, and where any interest in the subsid/i.rightary remains, this is remeasured to its fair value and the change in carrying amount is recognised in the income statement.

## Associates and jo/i.rightnt arrangements

Joint arrangements are where two or more parties either have rights to the assets, and obligat/i.rightons of the jo/i.rightnt arrangement (jo/i.rightnt operations), or have rights to the net assets of the jo/i.rightnt arrangement (jo/i.rightnt venture). The Group evaluates the contractual terms of jo/i.rightnt arrangements to determine whether a jo/i.rightnt arrangement is a jo/i.rightnt operation or a jo/i.rightnt venture. The Group did not have any contractual interest in jo/i.rightnt operations.

## An associate is an entity over which the Group has sign/i.rightficant influence.

Investments in associates and jo/i.rightnt ventures are accounted for by the equity method of accounting and are in/i.righttially recognised at cost. The Group's investment in associates and jo/i.rightnt ventures includes goodwill ident/i.rightfied on acquis/i.righttion (net of any accumulated impa/i.rightrment loss).

The Group's share of its associates' and jo/i.rightnt ventures' post-acquis/i.righttion profits or losses is recognised in the income statement, and its share of post-acquis/i.righttion movements in other comprehensive income is recognised in reserves. The cumulative post-acquis/i.righttion movements are adjusted against the carrying amount of the investment. When the Group's share of losses in an associate or a jo/i.rightnt venture equals or exceeds its interest in the associate, includ/i.rightng any other unsecured receivables, the Group does not recognise further losses, unless it has incurred obligat/i.rightons or made payments on behalf of the associate or jo/i.rightnt venture.

Unrealised gains and losses on transactions between the Group and its associates and jo/i.rightnt ventures are elim/i.rightnated to the extent of the Group's interest in the associates and jo/i.rightnt ventures. At each balance sheet date, the Group assesses whether there is any object/i.rightve evidence of impa/i.rightrment in the investment in associates and jo/i.rightnt ventures. ## Sign/i.rightficant accounting estimates and judgements

The Group applies judgement in determin/i.rightng if it has control, jo/i.rightnt control or sign/i.rightficant influence over subsid/i.rightaries, jo/i.rightnt ventures and associates respectively. These judgements are based upon ident/i.rightfying the relevant activ/i.rightties of counterparties, being those activ/i.rightties that sign/i.rightficantly affect the entit/i.rightes' returns, and further making a decis/i.righton of if the Group has control over those entit/i.rightes, jo/i.rightnt control, or has sign/i.rightficant influence (being the power to partic/i.rightpate in the financ/i.rightal and operating policy decis/i.rightons but not control them).

## Business combinat/i.rightons

The acquis/i.righttion method of accounting is used to account for the acquis/i.righttion of subsid/i.rightaries by the Group. ## 33. Structured entit/i.rightes

## Accounting policy

A structured entity is an entity that has been designed so that voting or sim/i.rightlar rights are not the dominant factor in decid/i.rightng who controls the entity. Contractual arrangements determine the rights and therefore relevant activ/i.rightties of the structured entity. Structured entit/i.rightes are generally created to achieve a narrow and well-defined object/i.rightve with restrict/i.rightons around their activ/i.rightties. Structured entit/i.rightes are consolidated when the substance of the relationsh/i.rightp between the Group and the structured entity ind/i.rightcates the Group has power over the contractual relevant activ/i.rightties of the structured entity, is exposed to variable returns, and can use that power to affect the variable return exposure.

In determin/i.rightng whether to consolidate a structured entity to which assets have been transferred, the Group takes into account its abil/i.rightty to direct the relevant activ/i.rightties of the structured entity. These relevant activ/i.rightties are generally evidenced through a unilateral right to liqu/i.rightdate the structured entity, investment in a substantial proportion of the securit/i.rightes issued by the structured entity or where the Group holds specif/i.rightc subordinate securit/i.rightes that embody certain controlling rights. The Group may further consider relevant activ/i.rightties embedded with/i.rightn contractual arrangements such as call options which give the practical abil/i.rightty to direct the entity, special relationsh/i.rightps between the structured entity and investors, and if a single investor has a large exposure to variable returns of the structured entity.

Judgement is required in determin/i.rightng control over structured entit/i.rightes. The purpose and design of the entity is considered, along with a determinat/i.righton of what the relevant activ/i.rightties are of the entity and who directs these. Further judgements are made around which investor is exposed to, and absorbs the variable returns of the structured entity. The Group will have to weigh up all of these facts to consider whether the Group, or another involved party is acting as a princ/i.rightpal in its own right or as an agent on behalf of others. Judgement is further required in the ongoing assessment of control over structured entit/i.rightes, specif/i.rightcally if market condit/i.rightons have an effect on the variable return exposure of different investors.

The Group has involvement with both consolidated and unconsolidated structured entit/i.rightes, which may be established by the Group as a sponsor or by a third-party.

Interests in consolidated structured entit/i.rightes: A structured entity is consolidated into the Group's financ/i.rightal statements where the Group controls the structured entity, as per the determinat/i.righton in the accounting policy above.
